subject_prompt_600:
Indo-Greek Kingdom was a Greek kingdom that existed in ancient times and had its seat at Samos in southern Greece. It has been mentioned many times but it is difficult to see how ancient Greece influenced it even slightly when the two countries were quite far apart geographically, geographically speaking.

The name Indo-Greek Kingdom was applied to all Greek kingdoms of antiquity by ancient Greeks who considered them as "Greeks without a Greek Empire" because they were not subject to any other Greek kingdoms or empires. This idea remains in the mind of people today and is still used today to label countries without any influence from Greek civilization.

The name Indo-Greek Kingdom is a very catchy name in the case of Indian students and scholars who are writing an essay on Indo-Greek Kingdom. If you are a scholar who wants to write an essay about India's history with the influence of Greek kingdom you need to remember that the term "infiltrated" is preferred over "contributed". "Infiltrated" refers to the fact that the people who made the contribution to the country were not Greek, nor Indians, but others who came from different regions of Europe.

When writing your paper do not forget to include the reference number when describing it in English, Greek and in other languages.

As an aside, I would like to share with you some interesting facts about Samos with reference to Indo-Greek Kingdom:

Samos is located in western Greece and its capital is Athens. Samos means "city of the sea" in ancient Greek and in modern Greek it is referred to as "Borgo Stromboli", meaning sea island. The city of Samos has an area of 2,400 hectares (5,000 acres) which is roughly one eighth of all the land in Greece. There are about 200 small islands off the coast of Samos and the total amount of islands has grown to over 1,600 islands, which is more than any other European country except Spain. About one fourth of these islands are inhabited. Most of the population of Samos are ethnic Greeks. Samos, and the islands of Kos and Kalolimnos, are home to over 90% of the Greek population in Greece, making them the second most populous island in Greece after Cyprus.

An interesting fact to mention is that Samos also borders Crete and Thessaly, two neighboring Aegean countries that have historically been neighbors.

If you are interested to learn about the early life of Samos you can read my earlier post about it

There are various theories about the origin of Samos. Some say that the name of this island came from Samos, the river in Southern Greece that comes from Euboea, an Ancient city of Phoenician origin near Athens. In modern Greek they call the river "Saimos" whereas in Old Greek it is called "Hercules".

It has also been suggested by some historians
coupled_prompt_600:
Mahadharmaraksita's original name was Kalyana Jyoti (Great Wonder) but has since been renamed to Mahadharma Mahadham. It is often referred to as the Buddha of India because of its teachings on peace, love and nonviolence. The first Sanskrit version of the Mahadharmaraksita was composed in the 4th century CE by Upanishads disciple Aṅgiriyātha. In India, Mahadharma Mahadham still stands tall among the best known Buddhist suttas, with the Bhagavad Gītā being the most famous. In Mahadhammapada, Mahadharmadham is compared to Indra, the sun god. Maha Mahadham is the one who is able to create the universe by his mind; the one who has the ultimate truth and wisdom.


Buddha - एक बीच पे खा न्य तूर तुम जलिया

(The Name that came from the One Who knows all things. The One Who has no passions or hatred.)

Bodhisattva - शोह्थे महस्तिष्टाड़्गाधाविष्टाड़्गयः

(A Great Being who is always without a hindrance and never suffering.)

Sutras:

Translations of Mahadharma Mahadham Sutras of Vārttikas (in various languages):

Buddha's Teachings on War and Peace


How to Live Peacefully with God


The Five Stages of Awakening


The Seven Stages of Serenity (Rigpa)


Kalyana Jyoti as a Source for Spiritual Knowledge
